trans-unit.source: Using Variables to Store Objects
trans-unit.target: Using Variables to Store Objects

trans-unit.source: powershell,cmdlet
trans-unit.target: powershell,cmdlet

trans-unit.source: Using Variables to Store Objects
trans-unit.target: Using Variables to Store Objects

trans-unit.source: Windows PowerShell works with objects.
trans-unit.target: Windows PowerShell works with objects.

trans-unit.source: Windows PowerShell lets you create variables - essentially named objects - to preserve output to use later.
trans-unit.target: Windows PowerShell lets you create variables - essentially named objects - to preserve output to use later.

trans-unit.source: If you are used to working with variables in other shells, remember that Windows PowerShell variables are objects, not text.
trans-unit.target: If you are used to working with variables in other shells, remember that Windows PowerShell variables are objects, not text.

trans-unit.source: Variables are always specified with the initial character $, and can include any alphanumeric characters or the underscore in their names.
trans-unit.target: Variables are always specified with the initial character $, and can include any alphanumeric characters or the underscore in their names.

trans-unit.source: Creating a Variable
trans-unit.target: Creating a Variable

trans-unit.source: You can create a variable by typing a valid variable name:
trans-unit.target: You can create a variable by typing a valid variable name:

trans-unit.source: This returns no result because **$loc** does not have a value.
trans-unit.target: This returns no result because **$loc** does not have a value.

trans-unit.source: You can create a variable and assign it a value in the same step.
trans-unit.target: You can create a variable and assign it a value in the same step.

trans-unit.source: Windows PowerShell only creates the variable if it does not exist; otherwise, it assigns the specified value to the existing variable.
trans-unit.target: Windows PowerShell only creates the variable if it does not exist; otherwise, it assigns the specified value to the existing variable.

trans-unit.source: To store your current location in the variable **$loc**, type:
trans-unit.target: To store your current location in the variable **$loc**, type:

trans-unit.source: There is no output displayed when you type this command because the output is sent to $loc.
trans-unit.target: There is no output displayed when you type this command because the output is sent to $loc.

trans-unit.source: In Windows PowerShell, displayed output is a side effect of the fact that data which is not otherwise directed always gets sent to the screen.
trans-unit.target: In Windows PowerShell, displayed output is a side effect of the fact that data which is not otherwise directed always gets sent to the screen.

trans-unit.source: Typing $loc will show your current location:
trans-unit.target: Typing $loc will show your current location:

trans-unit.source: You can use **Get-Member** to display information about the contents of variables.
trans-unit.target: You can use **Get-Member** to display information about the contents of variables.

trans-unit.source: Piping $loc to Get-Member will show you that it is a **PathInfo** object, just like the output from Get-Location:
trans-unit.target: Piping $loc to Get-Member will show you that it is a **PathInfo** object, just like the output from Get-Location:

trans-unit.source: Manipulating Variables
trans-unit.target: Manipulating Variables

trans-unit.source: Windows PowerShell provides several commands to manipulate variables.
trans-unit.target: Windows PowerShell provides several commands to manipulate variables.

trans-unit.source: You can see a complete listing in a readable form by typing:
trans-unit.target: You can see a complete listing in a readable form by typing:

trans-unit.source: In addition to the variables you create in your current Windows PowerShell session, there are several system-defined variables.
trans-unit.target: In addition to the variables you create in your current Windows PowerShell session, there are several system-defined variables.

trans-unit.source: You can use the **Remove-Variable** cmdlet to clear out all of the variables which are not controlled by Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: You can use the **Remove-Variable** cmdlet to clear out all of the variables which are not controlled by Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Type the following command to clear all variables:
trans-unit.target: Type the following command to clear all variables:

trans-unit.source: This will produce the confirmation prompt you see below.
trans-unit.target: This will produce the confirmation prompt you see below.

trans-unit.source: If you then run the **Get-Variable** cmdlet, you will see the remaining Windows PowerShell variables.
trans-unit.target: If you then run the **Get-Variable** cmdlet, you will see the remaining Windows PowerShell variables.

trans-unit.source: Since there is also a variable Windows PowerShell drive, you can also display all Windows PowerShell variables by typing:
trans-unit.target: Since there is also a variable Windows PowerShell drive, you can also display all Windows PowerShell variables by typing:

trans-unit.source: Using Cmd.exe Variables
trans-unit.target: Using Cmd.exe Variables

trans-unit.source: Although Windows PowerShell is not Cmd.exe, it runs in a command shell environment and can use the same variables available in any environment in Windows.
trans-unit.target: Although Windows PowerShell is not Cmd.exe, it runs in a command shell environment and can use the same variables available in any environment in Windows.

trans-unit.source: These variables are exposed through a drive named **env**:.
trans-unit.target: These variables are exposed through a drive named **env**:.

trans-unit.source: You can view these variables by typing:
trans-unit.target: You can view these variables by typing:

trans-unit.source: Although the standard variable cmdlets are not designed to work with **env:** variables, you can still use them by specifying the **env:** prefix.
trans-unit.target: Although the standard variable cmdlets are not designed to work with **env:** variables, you can still use them by specifying the **env:** prefix.

trans-unit.source: For example, to see the operating system root directory, you can use the command-shell **%SystemRoot%** variable from within Windows PowerShell by typing:
trans-unit.target: For example, to see the operating system root directory, you can use the command-shell **%SystemRoot%** variable from within Windows PowerShell by typing:

trans-unit.source: You can also create and modify environment variables from within Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: You can also create and modify environment variables from within Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Environment variables accessed from Windows PowerShell conform to the normal rules for environment variables elsewhere in Windows.
trans-unit.target: Environment variables accessed from Windows PowerShell conform to the normal rules for environment variables elsewhere in Windows.
